On Privacy and Personalization in
Cross-Silo Federated Learning

Ziyu Liu â€ƒShengyuan Hu â€ƒZhiwei Steven Wu â€ƒVirginia Smith
Carnegie Mellon University
{kzliu, shengyuanhu, zstevenwu, smithv}@cmu.edu
Abstract

While the application of differential privacy (DP) has been well-studied in cross-device federated learning (FL), there is a lack of work considering DP and its implications for cross-silo FL, a setting characterized by a limited number of clients each containing many data subjects. In cross-silo FL, usual notions of client-level DP are less suitable as real-world privacy regulations typically concern the in-silo data subjects rather than the silos themselves. In this work, we instead consider an alternative notion of silo-specific sample-level DP, where silos set their own privacy targets for their local examples. Under this setting, we reconsider the roles of personalization in federated learning. In particular, we show that mean-regularized multi-task learning (MR-MTL), a simple personalization framework, is a strong baseline for cross-silo FL: under stronger privacy requirements, silos are incentivized to federate more with each other to mitigate DP noise, resulting in consistent improvements relative to standard baseline methods. We provide an empirical study of competing methods as well as a theoretical characterization of MR-MTL for mean estimation, highlighting the interplay between privacy and cross-silo data heterogeneity. Our work serves to establish baselines for private cross-silo FL as well as identify key directions of future work in this area.

1 Introduction

Recent advances in machine learning often rely on large, centralized datasetsÂ [84, 23, 65], but curating such data may not always be viable, particularly when the data contains private information and must remain siloed across clients (e.g.Â mobile devices or hospitals). Recently, federated learningÂ (FL) [71, 50] has emerged as a paradigm for learning from such distributed data, but it has been shown that its data minimization principle alone may not provide adequate privacy protection for participantsÂ [101, 102]. To obtain formal privacy guarantees, there has thus been extensive work applying differential privacy (DP)Â [27, 28] to various parts of the FL pipeline (e.g.Â [32, 73, 41, 48, 4, 63, 44, 83, 34]).

Existing approaches for differentially private FL are typically designed for client-level DP in that they protect the federated clients, such as mobile devices (â€œuser-levelâ€), tasks in multi-task learning (â€œtask-levelâ€), or data silos like institutions (â€œsilo-levelâ€), and DP is achieved by clipping and noising the client model updates. While client-level DP is considered a strong privacy notion as all data of a single client is protected, it may not be suitable for cross-silo FL, where there are fewer clients but each hold many data subjects that require protection. For example, when hospitals/banks/schools wish to federate patient/customer/student records, it is the people owning those records rather than the participating silos that should be protected. In fact, laws and regulations may mandate such participation in FL be disclosed publiclyÂ [96], compromising the privacy of the federating clients.

In this work, we instead consider a more natural model of silo-specific sample-level privacy (Fig.Â 1, with variants appearing inÂ [41, 66, 109, 51]): the kğ‘˜k-th silo may set its own (Îµk,Î´k)subscriptğœ€ğ‘˜subscriptğ›¿ğ‘˜(\varepsilon_{k},\delta_{k}) sample-level DP target for any learning algorithm with respect to its local dataset. With this formulation in mind, we then reconsider the impact of privacy, heterogeneity, and personalization in cross-silo FL. In particular, we explore existing baselines for FL (mostly developed in cross-device settings) across private cross-silo benchmarks, and we find that the simple baseline of mean-regularized MTL (MR-MTL)

has many advantages for this setting relative to other more common (and possibly more complex) methods. We then further analyze the performance of MR-MTL under varying levels of heterogeneity and privacy, both in theory and practice. In addition to establishing baselines for cross-silo FL, we also identify interesting future directions in this area (SectionsÂ 7 andÂ G). We summarize our contributions below:111Code is available at https://github.com/kenziyuliu/private-cross-silo-fl.

  • â€¢

    We consider the notion of silo-specific sample-level differential privacy (DP) as a more realistic privacy model for cross-silo federated learning (FL). We analyze its implications on existing FL algorithms and, in particular, how it interfaces with data heterogeneity across silos.

  • â€¢

    We empirically show that mean-regularized multi-task learning (MR-MTL), a simple form of model personalization, is a remarkably strong baseline under silo-specific sample-level DP. Core to its effectiveness is its ability to (roughly) interpolate on the model personalization spectrum between local training and FedAvg with minimal privacy overhead.

  • â€¢

    We provide a theoretical analysis of MR-MTL under mean estimation and characterize how MR-MTL navigates the tension between privacy and cross-silo data heterogeneity.

  • â€¢

    Finally, we examine the complications of deploying an optimal MR-MTL instance that stem from the privacy cost of hyperparameter tuning. Our reasoning also applies to other personalization methods whose advantage over local training and/or FedAvg hinges on selecting the best hyperparameter(s). This raises important questions around the practicality of leveraging personalization to balance the emerging tradeoffs under silo-specific sample-level DP.

2 Preliminaries

Federated Learning (FL)Â [71, 58, 50] is a distributed learning paradigm with an emphasis on data protection: in every training round, each client (participant) downloads the current global model from a central server, trains it with the local dataset, and uploads the model changes (instead of the data) back to the server, which then aggregates the changes into a new global model. A basic instantiation of FL is FedAvgÂ [71], where clients are stateless and the server performs a simple (weighted) average. Cross-device FL refers to settings with many clients each with limited data, bandwidth, availability, etc. (e.g.Â mobile devices). In contrast, cross-silo FL typically involves less clients (e.g.Â banks, schools, hospitals) but each with more resources. Two distinguishing characteristics of cross-silo FL relevant to our work are that (1) silos may have sufficient data to fit a reasonable local model without FL, and (2) each data point in a silo tends to map to a data subject (a person) requiring privacy protection.

Differential Privacy (DP).â€‚Despite its ability to mitigate systemic privacy risks, FL by itself does not provide formal privacy guarantees for participantsâ€™ dataÂ [50, 102, 101], and differential privacy is often used in conjunction with FL to ensure that an algorithm does not leak the privacy of its inputs.

Definition 2.1 (Differential PrivacyÂ [27, 28]).

A randomized algorithm M:ğ’³nâ†’ğ’´:ğ‘€â†’superscriptğ’³ğ‘›ğ’´M:\mathcal{X}^{n}\to\mathcal{Y}, where ğ’³nsuperscriptğ’³ğ‘›\mathcal{X}^{n} is the set of datasets with nğ‘›n samples and ğ’´ğ’´\mathcal{Y} is the set of outputs, is (Îµ,Î´)ğœ€ğ›¿(\varepsilon,\delta)-DP if for any subset SâŠ†ğ’´ğ‘†ğ’´S\subseteq\mathcal{Y} and any neighboring x,xâ€²ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥â€²x,x^{\prime} differing in only one sample (by replacement), we have

To apply DP to a dataset query, one commonly used method is the Gaussian mechanismÂ [28], which involves bounding the contribution (â„“2superscriptâ„“2\ell^{2}-norm) of each sample in the dataset followed by adding Gaussian noise proportional to that bound onto the aggregate. To apply DP in FL, one needs to define the â€œdatasetâ€ to protect; typically, as in client-level DP, this is the set of FL participants and thus the model updates from each participant in every round should be bounded and noised. In learning settings, we need to repeatedly query a dataset and the privacy guarantee composes. We use DP-SGDÂ [92, 11, 1] for ensuring sample-level DP for model training, and we use RÃ©nyi DPÂ [77] and zCDPÂ [15] for tight privacy composition. In certain FL algorithms, clients also perform additional work such as cluster selectionÂ [69, 33] that incurs privacy overhead with respect to its local dataset that must be accounted for independently from DP-SGD. See AppendixÂ A for additional background.

Personalized FL.â€‚Model personalization is a key technique for improving utility under data heterogeneity across silos.222Note that â€œpersonalizationâ€ refers to customizing models for each client in FL rather than a specific person. Past work has examined the roles of local adaptationÂ [99, 104, 19], multi-task learningÂ [91, 89], clusteringÂ [33, 22, 69, 89], public dataÂ [108, 69], meta learningÂ [46, 56, 31], or other forms of model mixturesÂ [61, 57, 69, 38, 24, 3]. Notably, many methods leverage extra computation to some extent (e.g.Â extra iterationsÂ [61, 57, 19] or cluster selectionÂ [33, 69]), which will result in privacy overhead under silo-specific sample-level DP as discussed in the following section. Of particular interest is the family of mean-regularized multi-task learning (MR-MTL) methodsÂ [30, 94, 38, 37] (see AlgorithmÂ A1 for a typical instantiation). We find that MR-MTL, while extremely simple, is a strong baseline for private cross-silo FL.

3 Revisiting the Privacy Model for Cross-Silo Federated Learning

To date, the prevalent privacy model for federated learning has been to protect the participating clients, i.e.Â client-level DP. For cross-silo FL, however, several factors render client-level DP less appropriate. First, cross-silo FL often involves a small number of clients and it can be utility-wise more costly to attain the same privacy targets. For example, privacy amplification via samplingÂ [1, 78] may not apply on the client level since all silos typically participate in every round. Second, many existing methods focus on enforcing client-level DP in a non-local model and thus defines a shared privacy target for all participants, but in real-world cross-silo settings, participants under different jurisdictions (e.g.Â states) may have varying privacy requirements and thus opt for different privacy-utility tradeoffs. Third, while silo-level protection implies sample-level protection, it may be too stringent in practice as silos often have large local datasets. These unique properties for private cross-silo learning motivate us to consider silo-specific sample-level DP as an alternative privacy model (Fig.Â 1):

Definition 3.1 (Silo-specific sample-level DP).

A cross-silo FL algorithm with Kğ¾K clients (silos) satisfy {(Îµk,Î´k)}kâˆˆ[K]subscriptsubscriptğœ€ğ‘˜subscriptğ›¿ğ‘˜ğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ¾\{(\varepsilon_{k},\delta_{k})\}_{k\in[K]}-â€œsilo-specific sample-level DPâ€ if the local (personalized) model Mksubscriptğ‘€ğ‘˜M_{k} of every silo kâˆˆ[K]ğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ¾k\in[K] satisfies (Îµk,Î´k)subscriptğœ€ğ‘˜subscriptğ›¿ğ‘˜(\varepsilon_{k},\delta_{k})-DP w.r.t.Â the siloâ€™s local dataset of training examples.

Characteristics of silo-specific sample-level privacy.â€‚Importantly, silo-specific sample-level DP is defined over the disjoint datasets of the individual silos, rather than the combined dataset of all silos.333 A record in such a combined dataset is at most (maxiâ¡Îµisubscriptğ‘–subscriptğœ€ğ‘–\max_{i}\varepsilon_{i}, maxiâ¡Î´isubscriptğ‘–subscriptğ›¿ğ‘–\max_{i}\delta_{i})-DPÂ [76, 103, 63]. Moreover, if multiple records (either within a silo or across silos) map to the same person, then it is more intricate to protect the person rather than their records. Here we focus on the case where each entity has at most one record across the combined dataset (e.g.Â students attending exactly one school). See AppendixÂ B for discussions. To instantiate this setup in FL, each silo can simply run DP-SGDÂ [92, 11, 1] with a noise scale calibrated to gradually spend its privacy budget over Tğ‘‡T training rounds, and return the noisy model update at each round. This privacy notion has several important implications on the dynamics of FL:

  1. 1.

    Silos incur privacy costs with queries to their data, but not with participation in FL. This follows from DPâ€™s robustness to post-processing: the silosâ€™ model updates in each round already satisfy their own sample-level DP targets, and participation by itself does not involve extra dataset queries (e.g.Â DP-SGD steps). In contrast, local training without communication can be kept noise-free under client-level DP, but participation in FL requires privatization. Two immediate consequences of the above are that (1) local training and FedAvg now have identical privacy costs, and (2) local finetuning for model personalization may no longer work as expected (Fig.Â 2).

  2. 2.

    Less reliance on a trusted server. As a corollary of the above, all model updates of silo kğ‘˜k satisfy (at least) (Îµk,Î´k)subscriptğœ€ğ‘˜subscriptğ›¿ğ‘˜(\varepsilon_{k},\delta_{k})-DP against external adversaries, including all other silos and the orchestrating serverÂ [28, 109]. In contrast, client-level DP under a non-local model necessitates some trust on the server, even for distributed DP methods (e.g.Â [29, 21, 48, 4, 20, 18]).

  3. 3.

    Tradeoff emerges between costs from privacy and heterogeneity. As privacy-perserving noises are added independently on each silo, they are reflected in silosâ€™ model updates and can thus be mitigated when the model updates are aggregated (e.g.Â via FedAvg), leading to a smaller utility drop due to DP for the shared model. On the other hand, federation also means that the shared model may suffer from client heterogeneity (non-iid data across silos). This intuition is observed in Fig.Â 2: while local training may outperform FedAvg without privacy (as a result of heterogeneity), the opposite can be true when privacy is added (as a result of noise variance reduction).

The first and last in the above are of particular interest because they suggest that model personalization can play a key and distinct role in our privacy setting. Specifically, local training (no FL participation) and FedAvg (full FL participation) can be viewed as two ends of a personalization spectrum with identical privacy costs; if local training minimizes the effect of data heterogeneity but enjoys no DP noise reduction, and contrarily for FedAvg, it is then natural to ask whether there exist personalization methods that lie in between and achieve better utility, and, if so, what methods would work best.

Related privacy settings.â€‚Past work on differentially private FL has concentrated on client-level DP and cross-device FL (e.g.Â [32, 74, 44, 34, 49, 48, 6]), and the application of DP in cross-silo FL, particularly where each silo defines its own DP targets for records of its own dataset, is relatively underexplored. Privacy notions closest to ours first appeared inÂ [95, 56, 41, 109, 66, 51, 63]. In [95], each client adds its own one-shot noise onto its outgoing update, but in learning scenarios this provides client-level protection. The works of [56, 66, 109, 41, 63] study analogous privacy notions, though they respectively focus on boosting utilityÂ [56], analyzing statistical ratesÂ [66], adapting FL to fğ‘“f-DPÂ [109, 25], applying security primitivesÂ [41], and learning a better global model; the aspects of heterogeneity, DP noise reduction, the personalization spectrum, and their interplay (e.g.Â Figs.Â 2 andÂ 5) were unexplored. The work of [51] also considers a similar privacy notion, but the authors study a disparate trust assumption where DP noise is not added to local training/finetuning such that the final personalized models lack privacy guarantees. We note that the trust model most suitable for private cross-silo FL may be application-specific; in this work, we focus on the setting where the outputs of the FL procedure (the personalized models) must remain differentially private.

4 Baselines for Private Cross-Silo Federated Learning

With the characteristics from SectionÂ 3 in mind, we now explore various methods on cross-silo benchmarks. We defer additional details as well as results on more settings and datasets to the appendix.

Datasets. We consider four cross-silo datasets that span regression/classification and convex/non-convex tasks: VehicleÂ [26], SchoolÂ [35], Google Glass (GLEAM)Â [82], and CIFAR-10Â [53]. The first three datasets have real-world cross-silo characteristics: Vehicle contains measurements of road segments for classifying the type of passing vehicles, School contains student attributes for predicting exam scores, and GLEAM contains motion tracking data to classify wearersâ€™ activities. CIFAR-10 has heterogeneous client splits followingÂ [94, 90]. See SectionÂ C.1 for more details and datasets.

Benchmark methods. We consider several representative methods in the personalized FL literature beyond local training and FedAvgÂ [71]: local finetuningÂ [99, 104, 19] (a simple but strong baseline for model personalization), DittoÂ [57] (state-of-the-art personalization method), MochaÂ [91] (personalization with task relationship learning), IFCA/HypClusterÂ [33, 69] (state-of-the-art hard clustering method for client models), and the mean-regularized multi-task learning (MR-MTL) methodsÂ [30, 94, 38, 37] (which we analyze in SectionÂ 5). For fair comparison under silo-specific sample-level DP, we align all benchmark methods on the total privacy budget by first restricting the total number of iterations over the local datasets and then account for any privacy overheads (in the form of necessary extra stepsÂ [57] or cluster selection for IFCA/HypClusterÂ [33, 69]). Importantly, many other personalization methods can either be reduced to one of the above under convex settings (e.g.Â [46, 61]) or are unsuitable due to large privacy overheads (e.g.Â large factor of extra steps for [31]).

Training setup.â€‚For all methods, we use minibatch DP-SGD in each silo to satisfy silo-specific sample-level privacy; while certain methods may have more efficient solvers (e.g.Â dual form forÂ [91]), we want compatibility with DP-SGD as well as privacy amplification via sampling on the example level for tight accounting. For all experiments, silos train for 1 local epoch in every round (except forÂ [57] which runs â‰¥\geq 2 epochs). Hyperparameter tuning is done via grid search for all methods. Importantly, when comparing the benchmark methods, we do not account for the privacy cost of hyperparameter tuning in order to focus on their inherent privacy-utility tradeoff; we revisit this issue in SectionÂ 7. For simplicity, we use the same privacy budget for all silos, i.e.Â (Îµi,Î´i)=(Îµj,Î´j)subscriptğœ€ğ‘–subscriptğ›¿ğ‘–subscriptğœ€ğ‘—subscriptğ›¿ğ‘—(\varepsilon_{i},\delta_{i})=(\varepsilon_{j},\delta_{j}) for all i,jâˆˆ[K]ğ‘–ğ‘—delimited-[]ğ¾i,j\in[K]; note that this is not a restrictive assumption since the effect of having varying DP noise scales from different budgets can be attained by varying local dataset sizes.

Results.â€‚Fig.Â 3 shows the privacy-utility tradeoffs across four datasets. We observe that MR-MTL consistently outperforms a suite of baseline methods, and that it performs at least as good as local training and FedAvg (endpoints of the personalization spectrum), except at high-privacy regimes (possibly different for each dataset). In particular, there exists a range of Îµğœ€\varepsilon values where MR-MTL can give significantly better utility over local training and FedAvg under the same privacy budgets (Îµâ‰ˆ0.5,6,1.5ğœ€0.561.5\varepsilon\approx 0.5,6,1.5 for Fig.Â 3 (a, b, c) respectively); this is our key regime of interest.

Effects of silo-specific sample-level privacy.â€‚In Fig.Â 2 we saw that local finetuning may not improve utility as expected, motivating us to reconsider the roles of federation and personalization (SectionÂ 5 below). In Fig.Â 4, we consider the implication of silo-specific sample-level DP from the effects of privacy overhead due to additional dataset queries: (1) If IFCAÂ [33, 69] performs cluster selection at every round (default behavior), then the extra privacy cost can be prohibitive; (2) Despite its similarity to MR-MTL, DittoÂ [57]â€™s privacy overhead makes it less competitive (see alsoÂ Fig.Â 5).

5 On the Effectiveness of Mean-Regularized MTL for Private Cross-Silo FL

Following the observations in SectionÂ 4, we now examine the desirable properties of a good algorithm under silo-specific sample-level privacy and understand why MR-MTL may be an attractive candidate.

Federation as noise reduction.â€‚A key message from SectionÂ 3 and Fig.Â 2 is that the utility cost from DP can be significantly smaller for FedAvg compared to local training even when the latter spends an identical privacy budget. This implies that FedAvg may have inherent benefits for DP noise reduction, despite the noise are added in the gradient space rather than the parameter space (as in client-level DP). indeed implies that each siloâ€™s model update has an independent Gaussian random walk componentÂ [88, 7, 100] whose variance can be reduced by averaging with other silosâ€™ updates, as in FedAvg.444 The work ofÂ [49] examines the benefits of adding negatively correlated (instead of independent) noises ztsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘¡z_{t} across time steps. While this is a potential orthogonal extension to our use of local DP-SGD within each silo, it may not be directly applicable to our main focus of reducing noise variance across silos, since for each silo kğ‘˜k to satisfy its own (Îµk,Î´k)subscriptğœ€ğ‘˜subscriptğ›¿ğ‘˜(\varepsilon_{k},\delta_{k}) requirement, it must add noise independent to other silos. A similar reasoning applies to SGD cases since the additive DP noises are i.i.d.Â across the minibatches.

Model personalization for privacy-heterogeneity cost tradeoff.â€‚A major downside of FedAvg is that it may underperform simple local training due to data heterogeneity (e.g.Â [104] and Fig.Â 2), particularly given that clients in cross-silo FL often have sufficient data to fit reasonable local models. This suggests an emerging role for model personalization on top of its benefits in terms of utilityÂ [99], robustnessÂ [104], or fairnessÂ [57] under heterogeneity: our privacy model allows local training and FedAvg to be viewed as two endpoints of a personalization spectrum that respectively mitigate the utility costs of heterogeneity and privacy noise with identical privacy budgets (recall SectionÂ 3); this means that personalization methods could be viewed as interpolating between these endpoints and that various personalization methods essentially do so in different ways. However, our empirical observations motivate the following key properties of a good personalization algorithm:

  1. 1.

    Noise reduction: The effect of noise reduction is present throughout training so that the utility costs from DP can be consistently mitigated. Local finetuning is a counter-example (Fig.Â 2).

  2. 2.

    Minimal privacy overhead: There are little to no additional local dataset queries to prevent extra noise for DP-SGD under a fixed privacy budget. In effect, such privacy overhead can shift the utility tradeoff curve downwards, and DittoÂ [57] may be viewed as a counter-example (Fig.Â 4).

  3. 3.

    Smooth interpolation along the personalization spectrum: The interpolation between local training and FedAvg should be fine-grained (if not continuous) such that an optimal tradeoff should be attainable. ClusteringÂ [33, 69] may be viewed as a counter-example when there are no clear heterogeneity strucutre across clients.

These properties are rather restrictive and they render many promising algorithms less attractive. For example, model mixtureÂ [61, 13, 24] and local adaptationÂ [104, 19] methods can incur linear overhead in dataset iterations, and so can multi-task learningÂ [57, 91, 89] methods that benefit from additional training. Clustering methodsÂ [33, 22, 69, 89] can also incur overhead with cluster selectionÂ [33, 69], distillationÂ [22], or training restartsÂ [89], and they discretize the personalization spectrum in a way that depends on external parameters (e.g., the number of clients, clusters, or top-down partitions).

The case for mean-regularization.â€‚These considerations point to mean-regularized multi-task learning (MR-MTL) as one of the simplest yet particularly suitable forms of personalization. MR-MTL has manifested in various forms in the literatureÂ [30, 105, 94, 38, 19, 44] with the key idea that a personalized model wksubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜w_{k} for each silo kğ‘˜k should be close to the mean of all personalized models wÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¤\bar{w} via a regularization penalty Î»/2â€‹â€–wkâˆ’wÂ¯â€–22ğœ†2superscriptsubscriptnormsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜Â¯ğ‘¤22\nicefrac{{\lambda}}{{2}}\|w_{k}-\bar{w}\|_{2}^{2} (see AlgorithmÂ A1 for a typical instantiation). The hyperparameter Î»ğœ†\lambda serves as a smooth knob between local training and FedAvg, with Î»=0ğœ†0\lambda=0 recovering local training and a larger Î»ğœ†\lambda forces the personalized models wksubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜w_{k} to be closer to each other (â€œfederate moreâ€). However, it is an imperfect knob as Î»â†’âˆâ†’ğœ†\lambda\to\infty may not recover FedAvg under a typical optimization setup as the regularization term may dominate the gradient step wk(t+1)=wk(t)âˆ’Î·â€‹(gt+Î»â€‹(wk(t)âˆ’wÂ¯(t)))superscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜ğ‘¡1superscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜ğ‘¡ğœ‚subscriptğ‘”ğ‘¡ğœ†superscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜ğ‘¡superscriptÂ¯ğ‘¤ğ‘¡w_{k}^{(t+1)}=w_{k}^{(t)}-\eta\left(g_{t}+\lambda\left(w_{k}^{(t)}-\bar{w}^{(t)}\right)\right) where gtsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘¡g_{t} is the noisy clipped gradient, and MR-MTL may thus underperform FedAvg in high-privacy regimes that necessitate a large Î»ğœ†\lambda to mitigate DP noise (Fig.Â 3).

MR-MTL has the attractive properties that: (1) noise reduction is achieved throughout training via a soft constraint that personalized models are close to an averaged model; (2) for fixed Î»ğœ†\lambda it has zero additional privacy cost compared to local training/FedAvg as it does not involve extra dataset queries; and (3) Î»ğœ†\lambda provides a smooth interpolation along the personalization spectrum. Moreover, compared to other regularization-based MTL methods, it adds only one hyperparameter Î»ğœ†\lambda (cf.Â [45, 110, 36]); this has important practical implications as will be discussed in SectionÂ 7. It also has fast convergenceÂ [106] and easily extends to deep learning with good empirical performance in the primalÂ [94, 44] (cf.Â [10, 91, 64]). It is also sufficently extensible to handle structured heterogeneity (discussed below). We argue through the following empirical analyses that these properties make MR-MTL a strong baseline under silo-specific sample-level DP.

Navigating the emerging privacy-heterogeneity cost tradeoff. In Fig.Â 5 we study the effect of the regularization strength Î»ğœ†\lambda on the model utility directly. There are several notable observations: (1) In both private and non-private settings, Î»ğœ†\lambda serves to roughly interpolate between local training and FedAvg. (2) The utility at the best Î»âˆ—superscriptğœ†\lambda^{*} may outperform both endpoints. This is significant for the private setting since MR-MTL achieves an identical privacy guarantee as the endpoints. (3) Moreover, the advantage of MR-MTL over the best of the endpoints are also larger under privacy. (4) The value of Î»âˆ—superscriptğœ†\lambda^{*} also increases under privacy, indicating that the personalized silo models are closer to each other (i.e. silos are encouraged to â€œfederate moreâ€) for noise reduction. We will characterize these behaviors in SectionÂ 6. We also consider DittoÂ [57] in Fig.Â 5, a state-of-the-art personalization method that resembles MR-MTL and exhibits similar behaviors, to illustrate the effect of privacy overhead from its extra local training iterations.

MR-MTL under structured heterogeneity.â€‚We further study (1) the extensibility of MR-MTL as a strong baseline method to handle clustering structures of silo data distributions and (2) its flexibility to handle varying heterogeneity levels, by manually introducing two layers of heterogeneity to the MNIST datasetÂ [54]. The first layer is 4-way rotations: train/test images are evenly split into 4 groups of 10 silos, with each group applying {0âˆ˜,90âˆ˜,180âˆ˜,270âˆ˜}superscript0superscript90superscript180superscript270\{0^{\circ},90^{\circ},180^{\circ},270^{\circ}\} of rotation to their images. The second layer is silo-specific masking: each silo generates and applies its unique random mask of 2Ã—2222\times 2 white patches to its images, with varying masking probability. Together, the 1st layer creates 4 well-defined silo clusters, and the 2nd layer (gradually) adds intra-cluster heterogeneity. Importantly, our goal is not to contrive a utility advantage of MR-MTL (in fact, the added heterogeneity is disadvantageous to mean-regularization), but to examine its extensibility and flexibility as a strong baseline method to match the best methods by construction. Under the 1st layer of heterogeneity, clustered FL methodsÂ [33, 69] should be optimal if the correct clusters are formed since there is no intra-cluster heterogeneity; with increasing silo-specific heterogeneity in the 2nd layer, local training should be increasingly more attractive. See SectionÂ C.1 for more details on the setup and examples of images.

We propose a simple heuristic to precondition or â€œwarm-startâ€ MR-MTL with a small number of training rounds by running private clustering (with IFCAÂ [33, 69]) followed by mean-regularized training within each formed cluster (see AppendixÂ D for details). We find that this simple heuristic, with convergence properties carried forward from its componentsÂ [33, 30, 106], enables MR-MTL to excel at all levels of heterogeneity: in Fig.Â 6Â (a), the preconditioning allows MR-MTL to match IFCA (optimal by construction) while local training (full personalization) does not benefit from the same preconditioning; in Fig.Â 6Â (b, c, d), MR-MTL remains optimal across different levels of silo-specific heterogeneity (the 2nd layer) while the gains from warm-start gradually drop. We argue that extensibility and flexibility are good properties that make MR-MTL a strong baseline, as heterogeneity in practical settings is likely less adversarial than what we presented.

This could potentially help make heuristic or automated search over Î»ğœ†\lambda easier.

Theorem 6.8 (Private utility gap).

TheoremÂ 6.8 suggests that with a larger Î»ğœ†\lambda, the utility cost from privacy can be smoothly mitigated by up to a factor of Kğ¾K, matching the empirical observation in Fig.Â 5.

7 Discussions

In previous sections, we empirically and theoretically studied the benefits of the best personalization hyperparameter Î»âˆ—superscriptğœ†\lambda^{*} for MR-MTL, but it remains open as to how such Î»âˆ—superscriptğœ†\lambda^{*} may be obtained. In this section, we take an honest look at the complications of deploying MR-MTL through the lens of the privacy cost of finding Î»âˆ—superscriptğœ†\lambda^{*}. There are in general several approaches: (1) a non-adaptive search (e.g.Â grid/random searchÂ [12]); (2) an adaptive search (e.g.Â grad student descent); or (3) an online estimation during training (e.g.Â [97, 8, 80]). Here, we focus on approach (1) since it is generic to all personalization methods and is a setting for which we have the best privacy accounting toolsÂ [62, 79] to our knowledge. We defer technical details and further discussions to AppendixÂ F. Note that while we focus on MR-MTL, our reasoning in principle extends to all personalization methods whose advantage depends on having the best hyperparameter(s).

Recall that for a typical tuning procedure, a baseline algorithm Mğ‘€M is executed hâ„h times with different hyperparameters and the best result is recorded. The work ofÂ [62, 79] shows that, with a constant hâ„h, there exists Mğ‘€M that satisfies (Îµ,Î´=0)ğœ€ğ›¿0(\varepsilon,\delta=0)-DP where the output of tuning is not (Îµ~,0)~ğœ€0(\tilde{\varepsilon},0)-DP for any Îµ~<hâ€‹Îµ~ğœ€â„ğœ€\tilde{\varepsilon}<h\varepsilon, with analogous negative results for RÃ©nyi DP (thus also for Î´>0ğ›¿0\delta>0). This implies that naive tuning (as done in practice) can incur a prohibitive privacy overhead and obliterates the utility advantage of MR-MTL (Î»âˆ—superscriptğœ†\lambda^{*}) over local training/FedAvg. Instead, by making hâ„h random, we can make Îµ~~ğœ€\tilde{\varepsilon} constant w.r.t.Â hâ„h or at most Îµ~â‰¤Oâ€‹(logâ¡ğ„â€‹[h])~ğœ€ğ‘‚ğ„delimited-[]â„\tilde{\varepsilon}\leq O(\log\mathbf{E}[h])Â [62, 79]. However, using the simplified setting of mean estimation (SectionÂ 6), we find that even with this improved randomized protocol, there exist scenarios (Fig.Â 7) where the realistic cost of trying a moderate ğ„â€‹[h]=10ğ„delimited-[]â„10\mathbf{E}[h]=10 values of Î»ğœ†\lambda may significantly diminish, or even outweigh, the utility advantage of Î»âˆ—superscriptğœ†\lambda^{*} over local training and FedAvgâ€”that is, we might be better off by not privately tuning Î»ğœ†\lambda at all.

The above has several important implications. On the negative side, it suggests that the true efficacy of MR-MTL can be smaller in practice. Moreover, it raises the broader open question of whether the emerging privacy-heterogeneity cost tradeoff is best balanced by model personalization, as many existing methods including MR-MTL inherently require at least one hyperparameter to specify â€œhow much to personalizeâ€ for general utility improvements over local training and FedAvg. Alternatively, the hyperparameter(s) may be estimated during training (approach (3) in the first paragraph), though such procedures may not be general and/or scalable and may need to be tailored to the specific personalization method. On the positive side, it is unclear whether the choice of Î»ğœ†\lambda can meaningfully leak privacy in practice. MR-MTL may also be viewed favorably as a strong baseline since it only needs one hyperparameter to attain its benefits, while other existing methods that require more tuning will incur even larger privacy costs from hyperparameter tuning.

8 Concluding Remarks

In this work, we revisit the application of differential privacy in cross-silo FL. We examine silo-specific sample-level DP as a more appropriate privacy notion for cross-silo FL, and we point out several meaningful ways in which it differs from client-level DP commonly studied under the cross-device setting, particularly when analyzing tensions between privacy, utility, and heterogeneity. We explore and establish baselines under this privacy setting and identify desirable properties for a personalization method for balancing an emerging tradeoff between utility costs from privacy and heterogeneity. We then analyze a simple, promising method (MR-MTL) and discuss key open questions for the area at large. Some future directions include (1) extending the privacy model to cases where data subjects have multiple records across silos, (2) extending our theoretical characterization to deep learning cases or performing a large-scale empirical study, and (3) developing auto-tuning algorithms for personalization hyperparameters with minimal privacy overhead.

Zero-Concentrated Differential Privacy (zCDP).â€‚A closely related privacy notion is zero-concentrated DP (zCDPÂ [15]), where ÏğœŒ\rho-zCDP is equivalent to satisfying (Î±,Ïâ€‹Î±)ğ›¼ğœŒğ›¼(\alpha,\rho\alpha)-RÃ©nyi DP simultaneously for all orders Î±ğ›¼\alpha. In our work, we make use of zCDP and a related result for the Exponential MechanismÂ [87] for tight privacy composition when implementing private cluster selection for IFCAÂ [33, 69] (see below and SectionÂ C.3).

Exponential Mechanism for Private Selection.â€‚The Exponential Mechanism (EM) is a standard algorithm for making private selection from a set of candidates based on their scoresÂ [75]. Specifically, there is a dataset xâˆˆğ’³nğ‘¥superscriptğ’³ğ‘›x\in\mathcal{X}^{n} requiring DP protection, and a scoring function s:ğ’³nÃ—[G]â†’â„:ğ‘ â†’superscriptğ’³ğ‘›delimited-[]ğºâ„s:\mathcal{X}^{n}\times[G]\to\mathbb{R} that evaluates a set of candidates gâˆˆ[G]ğ‘”delimited-[]ğºg\in[G]. The Exponential Mechanism can be implemented as â€œReport Noisy Maxâ€ with Gumbel noise: we can add independent noises drawn from the Gumbel distribution with scale 2â€‹Î”Îµ2Î”ğœ€\frac{2\Delta}{\varepsilon} to the candidate scores sâ€‹(x,g)ğ‘ ğ‘¥ğ‘”s(x,g) for all gâˆˆ[G]ğ‘”delimited-[]ğºg\in[G] and simply report the max noisy score. If the score function is a loss metric (where we want the minimum instead of the maximum), we can similarly implement â€œReport Noisy Minâ€ by subtracting the Gumbel noises from the scores and report the minimum. The latter is used in our implementation for private cluster selection, where clients select clusters with lowest loss or error rate (i.e.Â 1âˆ’accuracy1accuracy1-\text{accuracy}); see SectionÂ C.3 for more details.

Privacy Budgeting.â€‚A typical accounting workflow, as used in our experiments, thus involves (1) composing the RDP guarantees of all private operations in the algorithm and (2) trying a list of Î±ğ›¼\alpha values that give the lowest Îµğœ€\varepsilon for a target Î´ğ›¿\delta when converting back to (Îµ,Î´)ğœ€ğ›¿(\varepsilon,\delta)-DP that captures the overall privacy cost. In a silo-specific sample-level DP setup, the size of the dataset nksubscriptğ‘›ğ‘˜n_{k} at each silo thus determines the extent of the amplification, and thus even if silos target for the same (Îµ,Î´)ğœ€ğ›¿(\varepsilon,\delta) sample-level DP, they may end up adding different amounts of noise when running DP-SGD (mentioned in the Training Setup paragraph of SectionÂ 4). For this reason our experiments primarily focus on having the same privacy target for all silos.

Heterogeneous Differential Privacy.â€‚A related privacy notion is heterogeneous DPÂ [5, 47], where each item within a dataset to be protected by DP may opt for a different (Îµ,Î´)ğœ€ğ›¿(\varepsilon,\delta) target. Our setting primarily focuses on different (Îµ,Î´)ğœ€ğ›¿(\varepsilon,\delta) values for disjoint datasets, and all items within a specific dataset share the same DP target.

See also AppendixÂ F for additional background relating to SectionÂ SectionÂ 7 (private hyperparameter tuning).

Appendix B Additional Discussions

B.1 Limitations

We discuss below the limitations of this work in addition to SectionÂ SectionÂ 7.

When multiple records map to the same entity. In this paper we studied the application of silo-specific sample-level differential privacy in cross-silo federated learning. While this is an important initial step towards a more suitable privacy model for cross-silo FL (in contrast to the commonly studied client-level DP model), we assume that each entity that requires privacy protection has at most one record (training example) across silos (e.g.Â a single patient has one medical record at a hospital).

There are two characteristic cases where this assumption does not hold for all items in a silo:

  • â€¢

    Multiple records within a silo map to the same entity. One example would be a student re-enrolling at the same school for multiple degree programs, thus creating multiple student records at the same silo. In such cases, the silo curator may need to carefully apply group privacy or other methods for ensuring entity-level privacyÂ [55] to protect the entity rather than its records.

  • â€¢

    Multiple records across silos map to the same entity. One example would be a person having multiple credit cards at different banks. This case is more intricate as it is harder to precisely account for the DP guarantee for this entity without knowing (1) the silos in which this entity has appeared and (2) the specific privacy targets for each of those silos. In this case, the silos may cooperate to run private set intersection (e.g. as considered inÂ [67]) to privately identify this scenario, but this would by itself come at a privacy cost.

These cases are interesting avenues for future research on private cross-silo learning.777The case of having individual records corresponding to multiple entities at once (e.g.Â one record for all family members) is slightly less interesting since sample-level privacy would protect all of the entities.

Extending the analysis to deep learning cases. In SectionÂ SectionÂ 6 we use federated mean estimation as a simplified setting for analyzing the behavior of MR-MTL under silo-specific sample-level privacy. While the analysis provides adequate insights into the empirical phenomena in Fig.Â 5, it is a simple model that does not consider the dynamic aspects of the learning settings, including (1) the Gaussian random walk component of the model updates due to DP noise applied over many training rounds, (2) the effect of communication frequency on the effect of noise reduction, (3) the concept of â€œclient driftsâ€ (as considered inÂ [52]) as a result of heterogeneity and how it interfaces with the DP noises, and (4) how overparameterization may affect all of the above.

Caveats of cross-silo learning with very large local datasets.

In contrast to cross-device federated learning, cross-silo federated learning is typically characterized by having a limited number of clients, each with a large local dataset. The term â€œlargeâ€ is relative because it describes the sufficiency of the datasets for fitting good local models of a specific class; for example, 500 examples are likely sufficient to fit linear regression of 10 parameters, but very likely insufficient to learn a transformerÂ [98]. In this sense, many FL problems in practice â€“ such as large commercial banks running regression on tabular data â€“ will in fact have local training to be the optimal strategy, as long as there are sufficient local data and the data from other silos are not of the same local distribution. In these cases, one should expect MR-MTL to opt for Î»âˆ—â‰ˆ0superscriptğœ†0\lambda^{*}\approx 0 as federated learning is not needed at all, and thus its advantages under privacy will also be minimal.

B.2 Potential Negative Societal Impact

Our work studies the empirical behaviors that arise when applying an alternative model of differential privacy to cross-silo federated learning, and we provide a strong baseline method (MR-MTL) that fares well in this setting. In this sense, our work sheds light on and facilitates the development of a previously underexplored area of differentially private federated learning. However, because MR-MTL requires selecting a good regularization stength Î»ğœ†\lambda, one potential negative impact is that users may excessively tune Î»ğœ†\lambda on a private dataset and inadvertently leak privacy via the choice of Î»ğœ†\lambda (perhaps qualitatively rather than quantitatively); for example, if a silo chose a large Î»ğœ†\lambda for better performance, then in principle its data would look somewhat more similar to the â€œaverageâ€ of the silo datasets. Moreover, our privacy model requires that silos add their own independent noises for their own DP targets, and this requirement may not be followed correctly (either deliberately or inadvertently) to provide vacuous DP guarantees for peopleâ€™s data.

Appendix C Additional Experimental Details

C.1 Datasets and Models

TableÂ A1 summarizes the datasets, tasks, and models considered in our experiments. In the following, we provide details on each.

VehicleÂ [26].â€‚The Vehicle Sensor dataset is a binary classification dataset containing K=23ğ¾23K=23 data silos. Each silo (sensor) has acoustic and seismic measurements for a road segment, with each data point being a 100-dimensional feature vector describing the measurements when a vehicle passes through the road segment. The goal is to predict between two predetermined types of vehicles. We use a train/test split of 75%/25% following previous workÂ [91], yielding 872â‰¤nktrainâ‰¤1933872superscriptsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘˜train1933872\leq n_{k}^{\text{train}}\leq 1933 training examples on each client. We use simple linear SVMs for classification followingÂ [91, 57]. It is a suitable dataset for cross-silo FL because the number of silos Kğ¾K is small while each silo has sufficient data to fit a good local model, as opposed to cross-device datasets such as FEMNISTÂ [16] where Kğ¾K is large but each silo has little data to learn a useful model. Moreover, we can use tight privacy budgets due to reasonably large local datasets (in terms of sufficiency for fitting a good local model) and SVMs (which are relatively noise-tolerant since decision boundaries only depend on support vectors). The dataset is accessible from the original authors.888https://web.archive.org/web/20110515133717/http://www.ece.wisc.edu:80/~sensit/

SchoolÂ [35, 9, 111].â€‚The School dataset originated from the now-defunct Inner London Education Authority.999https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inner_London_Education_Authority It is a regression dataset for predicting the exam scores of 15,362 students distributed across 139 secondary schools. Each school has records for between 22 and 251 students, and each student is described by a 28-dimensional feature vector capturing attributions such as the school ranking, student birth year, and whether the school provided free meals. We perform 80%/20% train/test split in Fig.Â 3 (with 15â‰¤nktrainâ‰¤17515superscriptsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘˜train17515\leq n_{k}^{\text{train}}\leq 175 training examples in each silo), and additionally consider 50%/50% and 20%/80% train/test split in Fig.Â A8. We use simple linear regression models following previous work (e.g.Â [9, 111, 36]) to predict student scores. Like the Vehicle dataset, the School dataset is a natural cross-silo FL dataset with a limited number of clients Kğ¾K, each with roughly sufficient data to fit a reasonable local model. The dataset is available fromÂ [111].

Google Glass Eating and Motion (GLEAM)Â [82].â€‚We also benchmark on the GLEAM dataset, a real-world head motion tracking dataset for binary classification. The motion data is collected with Google Glass, and the task is to classify the activity of the wearer (eating or not). There are in total K=38ğ¾38K=38 silos (wearers) and 27800 data points, with each silo containing 699â‰¤nkâ‰¤776699subscriptğ‘›ğ‘˜776699\leq n_{k}\leq 776 data points. Each data point is a 180-dimensional feature vector capturing head movement of the wearers. Linear models yield reasonable utility on GLEAM and thus we use linear SVMs following previous workÂ [91]. Like Vehicle and School, this is a suitable dataset for cross-silo FL given a small Kğ¾K and relatively large local datasets.

Heterogeneous CIFAR-10 Dataset.â€‚We additionally evaluate on CIFAR-10Â [53], with heterogeneous client data split following previous workÂ [94, 90] (based on the code provided byÂ [90]). The dataset has K=30ğ¾30K=30 clients (silos) in total, and data heterogeneity is generated with each client having a random number of samples from 5 randomly chosen classes out of the 10 classes. Each client has 1515â‰¤nkâ‰¤18391515subscriptğ‘›ğ‘˜18391515\leq n_{k}\leq 1839 training examples. We use a simple convolutional network with the following layers: [Conv 3Ã—3333\times 3 with 32 channels, ReLU, MaxPool 2Ã—2222\times 2 with stride 2, Conv 3Ã—3333\times 3 with 64 channels, ReLU, MaxPool 2Ã—2222\times 2 stride 2, Linear]. No padding is used for convolutional layers.

Rotated & Masked MNIST.â€‚We adapt the original MNIST datasetÂ [54] to study the effect of structured heterogeneity on MR-MTL. For the 60000/10000 train/test images, we first perform a shuffle and then evenly separate them into K=40ğ¾40K=40 clients (silos), each with 1500/250 train/test images with roughly uniform distribution on the labels. We then randomly separate the silos into 4 groups of 10, and apply rotations of {0âˆ˜,90âˆ˜,180âˆ˜,270âˆ˜}superscript0superscript90superscript180superscript270\{0^{\circ},90^{\circ},180^{\circ},270^{\circ}\} to each group respectively; silos within the same group have the same rotations applied to the images, thus forming 4 natural silo clusters. To add intra-cluster heterogeneity, we then apply silo-specific random masks of 2Ã—2222\times 2 white patches; that is, all images in the same silo has the same mask, and no two silos have the same mask with very high probability. The random masks are akin to those considered inÂ [40]. The white patches of the random mask do not overlap, and the mask ratio is the probability of a patch being applied (so the specified percentage of masked area is an expectation). Examples of generated images are shown in Fig.Â A1. These image transformations introduce two types of heterogeneity identified byÂ [50]: â€œcovariate shiftâ€ (skew of feature distributions) and â€œconcept driftâ€ (same label, different features). The model architecture is the same as the one used for heterogeneous CIFAR-10.

Subsampled Alzheimerâ€™s Disease Neuroimaging Initiative (ADNI) DatasetÂ [2].â€‚We additionally benchmark on the ADNI dataset, which is a real-world dataset containing brain PET scans of Alzheimerâ€™s disease patients, patients with mild cognitive impairment, and healthy people taken from multiple institutionsÂ [81]. It is a regression dataset for predicting the SUVR value (a scalar ranged roughly between 0.8 and 2) from the PET scan images of a brain. We simplified the full dataset for faster training by subsampling the axial slices generated for each brain PET scan (96 slices for scan), turning them into a gray scale image, downsampling them to size 32Ã—32323232\times 32, and randomly splitting them into a 75%/25% train/test sets. There are in total K=9ğ¾9K=9 silos containing a total of 11040 images; each silo corresponds to a different equipment that took the PET scans and contains 45â‰¤nktrainâ‰¤268545superscriptsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘˜train268545\leq n_{k}^{\text{train}}\leq 2685 training examples. See Fig.Â 4 of [86] and Fig. 4 ofÂ [81] for sample images. The model architecture is a simple convolutional network with the following layers: [Conv 5Ã—5555\times 5 with 32 channels, ReLU, MaxPool 2Ã—2222\times 2 with stride 2, Conv 5Ã—5555\times 5 with 64 channels, ReLU, MaxPool 2Ã—2222\times 2 stride 2, Linear]. No padding is used for convolutional layers.

C.3 Benchmark Methods and Implementation

We provide more details on our benchmark personalization methods below.

Local finetuningÂ [99, 104, 19] is one of the simplest but most effective personalization methods: once clients obtain a shared model via federated training (e.g.Â FedAvg), they can personalize it with additional training steps over their local dataset. This simple strategy has been shown to work very well empiricallyÂ [99, 104, 19], with the work ofÂ [19] providing theoretical support that it can asymptotically achieve comparable performance to other more sophisticated methods. Moreover, in contrast to other local adaptation methods like distillationÂ [104], local finetuningâ€™s privacy footprint under our privacy model can be easily controlled (by limiting the number of finetuning and total training steps) without qualitatives change in its behavior. In our experiments, local finetuning is implemented as FedAvg followed by local training, each taking 50% of the total number of training rounds to ensure an identical privacy budget as other baseline methods.

DittoÂ [57] is the current state-of-the-art method for personalization with provable benefits of robustness and fairness. It is closely related to MR-MTL because it similarly trains personalized models while â„“2superscriptâ„“2\ell^{2}-regularizing them towards a global model, but it differs from MR-MTL in that its global model can be obtained by a standalone solver. In particular, when no privacy is added, Dittoâ€™s modularity allows it to perfectly interpolate between local and FedAvg training with its regularization strength Î»ğœ†\lambda. In our experiments, we implement Ditto with the FedAvg solver and use a minimal number of iterations over the local datasets to avoid excessive privacy overhead.

MochaÂ [91] is a multi-task learning framework tailored for federated settings. During training, it simultaneously learns the personalized models as well as a client-relationship matrix which can model both positive and negative client relationships (in contrast, clustering methods only focus on positive relationships). One disadvantage of Mocha is that it applies to convex problems only. In particular, the original paper uses a dual formulation for efficient training, but for fair comparison and compatibility with privacy primitives (especially DP-SGDÂ [92, 11, 1]), we implemented Mocha in its primal form and trained it with SGD in our experiments. Similarly, we align Mocha to other baselines in terms of the number of training steps to prevent privacy overhead.

IFCAÂ [33] (and the conceptually similar HypClusterÂ [69]) is a simple clustering framework proposed as an extension to FedAvg. In every round of IFCA training, the server sends kğ‘˜k models (cluster centroids) to all clients; each client locally evaluates them over its local training data and selects the one with the lowest loss. Each client then locally trains on the selected model and returns updates only for this model, along with its index. Clients that selected the same model indices can be viewed as belonging to the same cluster. We use IFCA as the representative clustering method due to its performance, simplicity, and practicality.

The privacy overhead of IFCA comes in the form of private cluster selection: when each client evaluates the incoming models (cluster centroids) on the local datasets, this procedure must be privatized as the selection itself may leak information about the dataset. Private selection can be implemented via the exponential mechanismÂ [75] with sharp accounting via a bounded range analysisÂ [87] (discussed inÂ AppendixÂ A), but one must decide (e.g.Â as a privacy budget Îµselectsubscriptğœ€select\varepsilon_{\mathrm{select}} for the same Î´ğ›¿\delta) how to share the selection cost with DP-SGD under a fixed total privacy budget Îµtotalsubscriptğœ€total\varepsilon_{\mathrm{total}}.

Mitigating strategies for private cluster selection. In our experiments, we observed that if private selection is implemented naively, it can incur a prohibitive privacy overhead and destroys the final utility (e.g.Â Fig.Â 4). There are two important reasons: (1) unlike DP-SGD, no privacy amplification applies to private selection, and (2) the sensitivity of the training loss (which is used to select cluster centroids) is unbounded in general and must be clipped to a reasonable value (e.g. â‰¤1absent1\leq 1). We propose two mitigation strategies:

  1. 1.

    Use accuracy instead of loss. For the cluster selection metric (i.e.Â the score function sâ€‹(x,g)ğ‘ ğ‘¥ğ‘”s(x,g) where xğ‘¥x is the local dataset and gğ‘”g is a particular cluster centroid), we use the error rate (1âˆ’accuracy1accuracy1-\text{accuracy}) instead of the loss (which is used by the original authorsÂ [33, 69]). The rationale is that accuracy is a low-sensitivity function, particularly in cross-silo settings: one can show that, by enumerating the cases where the differing example between the neighboring datasets xğ‘¥x and xâ€²superscriptğ‘¥â€²x^{\prime} are correctly/incorrectly classified under addition/removal/replacement notions of DP, the sensitivity Î”accsubscriptÎ”acc\Delta_{\mathrm{acc}} of sğ‘ s is bounded as

    Î”accsubscriptÎ”acc\displaystyle\Delta_{\mathrm{acc}} =maxgâ¡maxx,xâ€²â¡|sâ€‹(x,g)âˆ’sâ€‹(x,gâ€²)|â‰¤1nâˆ’1absentsubscriptğ‘”subscriptğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥â€²ğ‘ ğ‘¥ğ‘”ğ‘ ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘”â€²1ğ‘›1\displaystyle=\max_{g}\max_{x,x^{\prime}}\left|s(x,g)-s(x,g^{\prime})\right|\leq\frac{1}{n-1} (15)

    where nğ‘›n is the size of the local dataset. Since nğ‘›n can be large in cross-silo settings, the sensitivity can be orders of magnitude smaller than that of the loss function. With small sensitivity, we heuristically set the per-round selection privacy budget to a very small Îµselect=0.03â‹…Îµtotalsubscriptğœ€selectâ‹…0.03subscriptğœ€total\varepsilon_{\text{select}}=0.03\cdot\varepsilon_{\text{total}}. Despite this, however, the cost of private selection can still grow quickly over the entire training process and considerably eat into DP-SGDâ€™s privacy budget.

  2. 2.

    Truncate the number of cluster selection rounds. Our second strategy is to simply run less rounds of cluster selection (e.g.Â to 10% of total number of training rounds, as in Fig.Â 3). This follows from the empirical analysis ofÂ [33] as well as our own experimental observation that clusters tend to converge quickly, though in some cases, clusters may not fully converge within 10% of training rounds.

Despite these strategies, however, the private selection cost can still lead to a steep utility hit. Note also that the new hyperparameter Îµselectsubscriptğœ€select\varepsilon_{\text{select}} can be tuned; for a fixed total budget Îµtotalsubscriptğœ€total\varepsilon_{\text{total}}, a small Îµselectsubscriptğœ€select\varepsilon_{\text{select}} means the budget for DP-SGD Îµtrainsubscriptğœ€train\varepsilon_{\text{train}} is not affected by much, but the selected clusters would be very noisy and inaccurate; a large Îµselectsubscriptğœ€select\varepsilon_{\text{select}} leads to less noisy clusters (and thus smaller intra-cluster heterogeneity), but DP-SGD will correspondingly use larger noise and hurt optimization.

C.4 Training Settings

Optimizers.â€‚For simplicity of hyperparameter tuning and experimental controls, we use minibatch DP-SGD for client local training without local or server momentum for all experiments (in fact, FedAvgMÂ [43] and FedAdamÂ [85] were not found to be helpful on Vehicle and School). While there are more efficient solvers for the Vehicle and School datasets since we are dealing with convex problems, we want compatibility with DP-SGDÂ [92, 11, 1] as well as tight privacy accounting with privacy amplification via subsampling (i.e.Â via minibatch training).

Hyperparameters.â€‚For all datasets and all methods, we set silos to train for 1 local epoch in every round (except DittoÂ [57] which takes 2 local epochs). For Vehicle, GLEAM, School, Heterogeneous CIFAR-10, Rotated & Masked MNIST, and subsampled ADNI respectively, the local batch size across all silos are fixed with B=64,64,32,100,100,64ğµ64643210010064B=64,64,32,100,100,64, and the clipping norm for per-example gradients are heuristically set to c=6,6,1,8,1,0.5ğ‘661810.5c=6,6,1,8,1,0.5. Vehicle uses T=400ğ‘‡400T=400 rounds for most experiments (except Fig.Â 2 which trains for T=200ğ‘‡200T=200 rounds); School, Google Glass, Heterogeneous CIFAR-10, and Rotated & Masked MNIST use T=200ğ‘‡200T=200; and ADNI uses T=500ğ‘‡500T=500.

For multi-task learning methods (MR-MTL, DittoÂ [57], MochaÂ [91]), we sweep the regularization strength across a grid of Î»âˆˆ[0.0001,0.001,0.003,0.01,0.03,0.1,0.3,1,3,10]ğœ†0.00010.0010.0030.010.030.10.31310\lambda\in[0.0001,0.001,0.003,0.01,0.03,0.1,0.3,1,3,10] to find the best Î»âˆ—superscriptğœ†\lambda^{*} wherever applicable (e.g.Â Figs.Â 3, 5 andÂ A8). To compensate for the change in the gradient magnitude, we also sweep different client learning rates across a grid of Î·âˆˆ[0.001,0.003,0.01,0.03,0.1,0.3]ğœ‚0.0010.0030.010.030.10.3\eta\in[0.001,0.003,0.01,0.03,0.1,0.3]; for fair comparison, the same grid of Î·ğœ‚\eta is swept for methods that do not involve Î»ğœ†\lambda (e.g.Â IFCA, local finetuning).141414As discussed in SectionÂ SectionÂ 7, releasing the results from repeated experiments (possibly with different hyperparameters) may technically compromise the privacy of the datasetsÂ [62, 79]. In our case, we are primarily interested in understanding the behaviors and tradeoffs that emerge under silo-specific sample-level DP, and thus for experimental control and ease of comparison we do not account for the privacy costs from hyperparameter tuning and repetitions. We also use only public datasets in our experiments. For Fig.Â 2 and Fig.Â A2, the learning rate is fixed to Î·=0.01ğœ‚0.01\eta=0.01. For all datasets, the chosen privacy parameter Î´ğ›¿\delta satisfy Î´<nkâˆ’1.1ğ›¿superscriptsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘˜1.1\delta<n_{k}^{-1.1} where nksubscriptğ‘›ğ‘˜n_{k} is the local training dataset size.

Evaluation Protocol.â€‚For all datasets, we evaluate methods by the average test metric (accuracy or MSE) across the silos, weighted by their respective test sample counts. Weighted averaging allows the final test metric to reflect a methodâ€™s performance over the individual test samples of the combined dataset across silos, thus fairer and more aligned (compared to uniform averaging of silo test metrics) with our privacy model where each test sample represents an entity requiring protection.

C.5 Hardware

Experiments for Vehicle, School, and Google Glass (GLEAM) are run on commodity CPUs and experiments for Heterogeneous CIFAR-10, Rotated & Masked MNIST and ADNI are run on four NVIDIA RTX A6000 GPUs.

C.6 Code

Our experiments are implemented in Python with NumPyÂ [39], JAXÂ [14] and HaikuÂ [42]. For private training, JAX is used to vectorize DP-SGD over per-example gradientsÂ [93]. Code is available at https://github.com/kenziyuliu/private-cross-silo-fl.

Appendix D Additional Algorithmic Details

D.1 Mean-Regularized Multi-Task Learning (MR-MTL)

AlgorithmÂ A1 describes the canonical instantiation of MR-MTLÂ [94]. Its key ingredient is the mean-regularization (Line 6 of AlgorithmÂ A1) that forces the local personalized models wksubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜w_{k} to be close to their mean wÂ¯Â¯ğ‘¤\bar{w}. Silo-specific sample-level privacy is added by privatizing the local gradients as in DP-SGDÂ [92, 11, 1].

Privacy of MR-MTL.â€‚Since the iterates of wÂ¯(t)superscriptÂ¯ğ‘¤ğ‘¡\bar{w}^{(t)} are already differentially private (as they are the average of the private iterates wk(t)superscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜ğ‘¡w_{k}^{(t)}), the additional regularization term Î»2â€‹â€–wk(t)âˆ’wÂ¯k(tâˆ’1)â€–22ğœ†2superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘¤ğ‘˜ğ‘¡122\frac{\lambda}{2}\|w_{k}^{(t)}-\bar{w}_{k}^{(t-1)}\|_{2}^{2} (and hence MR-MTL) does not incur privacy overhead compared to local and FedAvg training.

Weighted vs Unweighted Model Updates.â€‚It is customary to weigh the model updates from each client (silo) by its training example counts, as in the original FedAvg implementationÂ [71]. However, note that under silo-specific sample-level privacy with addition/removal notions of DP, the example counts on each silo may itself leak sensitive information (e.g.Â when a silo only has one record). This is less of an issue with the replacement notion of DP, since neighboring datasets would have the same example counts. In our experiments we use weighted model updates and thus implicitly assume the replacement notion of DP. Nevertheless, the resulting privacy guarantees are constant factors apart and empirically we did not observe significant changes in performance when using unweighted aggregation.

D.2 IFCA Preconditioning / Warm-Starting

In SectionÂ SectionÂ 5, we considered an extension to MR-MTL where training is â€œwarm-startedâ€ by a small number of rounds of clustering (via IFCAÂ [33, 69]), followed by MR-MTL training within each formed cluster. Pseudocode for this procedure is shown in AlgorithmÂ A2.

Privacy of IFCA Preconditioning.â€‚Observe that as with MR-MTL, the gradient steps satisfy silo-specific sample-level DP regardless or whether the steps are made on the cluster models or the personalized models. IFCA preconditioning introduces privacy overhead in the form of private cluster selection (Line 6 of AlgorithmÂ A2; discussed in AppendicesÂ A andÂ C.3), which splits the total privacy budget with DP-SGD. As a result the noise scale for DP-SGD would be increased and can be numerically determined.

E.2 MR-MTLÂ Formulation

The general formulation of the mean-regularized MTL objective may be expressed as

minwk,kâˆˆ[K]â€‹1Kâ€‹âˆ‘k=1Khkâ€‹(wk)withhkâ€‹(w)â‰œFkâ€‹(w)+Î»2â€‹â€–wâˆ’wÂ¯â€–22,â‰œsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜ğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ¾1ğ¾superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾subscriptâ„ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜withsubscriptâ„ğ‘˜ğ‘¤subscriptğ¹ğ‘˜ğ‘¤ğœ†2superscriptsubscriptnormğ‘¤Â¯ğ‘¤22\displaystyle\underset{w_{k},k\in[K]}{\min}\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}h_{k}(w_{k})\quad\text{with}\quad h_{k}(w)\triangleq F_{k}(w)+\frac{\lambda}{2}\|w-\bar{w}\|_{2}^{2}, (18)

where Fkâ€‹(â‹…)subscriptğ¹ğ‘˜â‹…F_{k}(\cdot) is the local objective for client kğ‘˜k, wÂ¯â‰œ1Kâ€‹âˆ‘k=1Kwkâ‰œÂ¯ğ‘¤1ğ¾superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜\bar{w}\triangleq\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}w_{k} is the average model, and Î»â‰¥0ğœ†0\lambda\geq 0 is the regularization strength. A larger Î»ğœ†\lambda enforces the models to be closer to each other, and Î»=0ğœ†0\lambda=0 reduces the problem to local training. For the purposes of our analysis, we assume Fksubscriptğ¹ğ‘˜F_{k} is strongly convex for all kâˆˆ[K]ğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ¾k\in[K].

E.3 Assumptions

Our characterization of MR-MTL on makes the following simplifying assumptions.

Assumption E.1.

All clients (silos) have the same number of data points nğ‘›n, data sampling variance Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2}, and DP noise variance ÏƒDP2superscriptsubscriptğœDP2\sigma_{\mathrm{DP}}^{2}.

Assumption E.2.

A sufficiently large clipping cğ‘c can be selected such that â€–xk,iâ€–2â‰¤csubscriptnormsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ‘–2ğ‘\|x_{k,i}\|_{2}\leq c with high probability.

Note that E.1 primarily serves to make results cleaner and easily interpretable (see SectionÂ E.5 for extensions). E.2 is mild since Gaussians have strong tail decay.

Proof.

TheoremÂ E.5 suggests that if silos have varying local variance (as a result of varying local dataset sizes, inherent data variances, and silo-specific sample-level DP requirements), then it is optimal to have each silo choose its own Î»kâˆ—subscriptsuperscriptğœ†ğ‘˜\lambda^{*}_{k}. Appendix F Additional Details for Private Hyperparameter Tuning (SectionÂ 7)

In SectionÂ SectionÂ 7 we took an alternative view on the benefits of personalization by examining the privacy cost of tuning the hyperparameter responsible for navigating the tradeoff between costs from heterogeneity and privacy. In this section, we expand on the omitted details and provide more discussions.

F.1 Additional Background on Privacy Costs of Hyperparameter Tuning

We consider the typical hyperparameter tuning procedure (denoted as HPO) where a base algorithm Mğ‘€M, such as one run of a machine learning algorithm to produce a model, is executed hâ„h times with different hyperparameters and the best result is recorded. The hyperparameters may be high-dimensional; e.g.Â vector of learning rate and batch size. Typically, hâ„h is a constant (e.g.Â we sweep a fixed grid of learning rates and batch sizes).

On a high level, the works of Liu and TalwarÂ [62] and Papernot and SteinkeÂ [79] show that, with a constant hâ„h, one can construct Mğ‘€M where the privacy guarantee of the HPO output is (roughly) a factor of hâ„h weaker than the original privacy guarantee. Specifically, [79] gives the following proposition that applies to both pure DP and RÃ©nyi DP (and thus related to approximate DP).

Proposition F.1 (Proposition 17 of [79]).

For any Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0 and any Î±>1ğ›¼1\alpha>1, there exist some algorithm Mğ‘€M that satisfy (Îµ,0)ğœ€0(\varepsilon,0)-DP and the corresponding HPO algorithm Ağ´A that runs Mğ‘€M for hâ„h times and returns only the best result, such that

  1. 1.

    Ağ´A is not (Îµ~,0)~ğœ€0(\tilde{\varepsilon},0)-DP for any Îµ~<hâ€‹Îµ~ğœ€â„ğœ€\tilde{\varepsilon}<h\varepsilon, and

  2. 2.

    Ağ´A is not (Î±,Îµ~â€‹(Î±))ğ›¼~ğœ€ğ›¼(\alpha,\tilde{\varepsilon}(\alpha))-RÃ©nyi DP for any Îµ~â€‹(Î±)<Îµ^â€‹(Î±)~ğœ€ğ›¼^ğœ€ğ›¼\tilde{\varepsilon}(\alpha)<\hat{\varepsilon}(\alpha) where

    Îµ^â€‹(Î±)=hâ€‹Îµâˆ’hâ€‹logâ¡(1+expâ¡(âˆ’Îµ))Î±âˆ’1.^ğœ€ğ›¼â„ğœ€â„1ğœ€ğ›¼1\displaystyle\hat{\varepsilon}(\alpha)=h\varepsilon-\frac{h\log(1+\exp(-\varepsilon))}{\alpha-1}. (49)

Both the pure DP and RDP results suggest that running the typical HPO procedure with a fixed hâ„h can be as bad as running Mğ‘€M and hâ„h times and releasing all results.

The authors of [62] and [79] provided a mitigating strategy where one simply makes hâ„h (the number of tuning runs) a random variable. The authors ofÂ [79] provide an improved analysis and considered two distributions for hâ„h in particular: the truncated negative binomial (TNB) distribution and the Poisson distribution.

Here, we focus on TNB as it provides a spectrum of results for privacy-utility tradeoff, allowing us to choose several points on this spectrum that offer small (but realistic) privacy overhead. We combine it our analysis in SectionÂ SectionÂ 6 to motivate our discussions on the practical complications of deploying personalization methods.

Specifically, the probability mass function of the TNB distribution is given by

where Î·ğœ‚\eta and Î³ğ›¾\gamma are parameters of the TNB distribution. The privacy of the HPO output using hâ„h sampled from the TNB distribution is given by the following theorem fromÂ [79].

Theorem F.2 (Theorem 2 of [79]).
