TheoremÂ F.2 tells us that by drawing hâ„h from the TNB distribution, the privacy cost of the HPO procedure is a constant factor of the original cost of Mğ‘€M for pure DP (when Î±1,Î±2â†’âˆâ†’subscriptğ›¼1subscriptğ›¼2\alpha_{1},\alpha_{2}\to\infty), or up to a factor of logâ¡ğ„â€‹[h]ğ„delimited-[]â„\log\mathbf{E}[h] for approximate DP. This substantially improves the default HPO procedure.

F.2 Interpretation of Fig.Â 7

In Fig.Â 7, we considered 6 pairs of (Î·,Î³)ğœ‚ğ›¾(\eta,\gamma) to arrive at the same ğ„â€‹[h]=10ğ„delimited-[]â„10\mathbf{E}[h]=10 (i.e.Â on average we want to try 10 values of Î»ğœ†\lambda when tuning MR-MTL). Intuitively, for a fixed ğ„â€‹[h]ğ„delimited-[]â„\mathbf{E}[h], we can expect a smaller Î·ğœ‚\eta (and consequently a smaller Î³ğ›¾\gamma) to give a tighter privacy guarantee from TheoremÂ F.2 (i.e.Â the privacy cost of hyperparameter tuning is smaller). At the same time, however, the TNB distribution would be more concentrated around h=1â„1h=1 with a smaller Î·ğœ‚\eta, which means we may end up trying only 1 hyperparameter even when ğ„â€‹[h]ğ„delimited-[]â„\mathbf{E}[h] is large. (Î·,Î³)ğœ‚ğ›¾(\eta,\gamma) thus provides an implicit privacy-utility tradeoff.

In Fig.Â 7 we chose a list of Î·ğœ‚\eta values that favors strong privacy while being realistic, since picking Î·â†’âˆ’1â†’ğœ‚1\eta\to-1 (or just Î·<âˆ’0.5ğœ‚0.5\eta<-0.5) would give a even smaller privacy overhead, but it will perform very poorly utility-wise and was not considered byÂ [79]. We then applied TheoremÂ F.2 with these (Î·,Î³)ğœ‚ğ›¾(\eta,\gamma) values to the the expected error of MR-MTL as a function of Î»ğœ†\lambda under mean estimation, by computing and applying the extra noise needed to account for the privacy cost of tuning. Here, the closed form of the expected error of MR-MTL is derived in LemmaÂ 6.7, but in Fig.Â 7 we ran numerical simulations with 500 repetitions.

Fig.Â 7Â (a) and (c) suggests that there are settings in which, after applying TheoremÂ F.2, the best Î»âˆ—superscriptğœ†\lambda^{*} one could find would already give an error that is larger than simply running FedAvg and local training without any tuning, respectively (the green curves). Fig.Â 7Â (b) suggests that in less extreme cases, the private hyperparameter tuning cost would significantly diminish the utility improvement of MR-MTL.

F.3 Implementing Hyperparameter Tuning under Silo-Specific Sample-Level DP

Under silo-specific sample-level privacy, it can be intricate to implement the improved, randomized hyperparameter tuning protocol described above inÂ SectionÂ F.1. For silo kğ‘˜k to satisfy its own (Îµk,Î´k)subscriptğœ€ğ‘˜subscriptğ›¿ğ‘˜(\varepsilon_{k},\delta_{k}) sample-level DP target, it must draw hâ„h independently to all other silos, and it must only return the best result of hyperparameter tuning at the end of training (instead of returning the best model iterate at every round).

Using MR-MTL as an example, the above has several implications:

  1. 1.

    Each silo should now maintain a list of personalized models, each corresponding to a choice of Î»ğœ†\lambda.

  2. 2.

    Depending on the specific distribution of hâ„h, silos may or may not end up trying the same set of Î»ğœ†\lambda values.

  3. 3.

    During training rounds, silos must return model updates for â€“ and consequently regularize their personalized models towards â€“ a â€œpivotâ€ model using some public Î»Â¯Â¯ğœ†\bar{\lambda}.

The analysis in SectionÂ E.5 suggests that having silo-specific choices of Î»ğœ†\lambda (#2 above) should not have adverse effects, but the above adaptations in general may influence final utility or convergence properties in iterative learning settings.

Other more sophisticated implementation (potentially tailored to the specific personalization method) may also be possible. It would be an interesting future direction to study the best approaches for implementing private hyperparameter tuning under silo-specific sample-level privacy.

Appendix G Future Directions for Auto-tuning / Online Estimation of Î»ğœ†\lambda

Apart from tuning Î»ğœ†\lambda for MR-MTL (or other hyperparameters for other personalization methods) non-adaptively with grid search or random search, another approach is to leverage some form of online estimation as inÂ [97, 8, 80] (mentioned in SectionÂ SectionÂ 7). That is, Î»ğœ†\lambda is adjusted at every training round or iteration such that it gradually converges to a good Î»âˆ—superscriptğœ†\lambda^{*} (in expectation).

This line of approaches would be promising if their privacy overhead (if any) can be contained within a small factor of the original privacy guaranteeâ€”smaller than that offered by the randomized tuning procedure discussed above in SectionÂ F.1. However, since the hyperparameters of interest are those that navigate the tradeoff between costs from heterogeneity and privacy (such as Î»ğœ†\lambda for MR-MTL), there are several factors that make auto-tuning particularly challenging in our setting:

  • â€¢

    A universal and practical measure of heterogeneity is generally unavailable. For MR-MTL, our analysis in SectionÂ SectionÂ 6 suggests that the optimal Î»âˆ—superscriptğœ†\lambda^{*} depends on a measure of data heterogeneity across silos (Ï„2superscriptğœ2\tau^{2}). However, in practice, the level of heterogeneity is abstract and hard to quantify even with non-private oracle access to the silo datasets. Past work has devised custom measures of heterogeneity such as the variance of client (silo) model or gradient updatesÂ [52, 59], or the difference between the true global loss and the aggregate of the true local losses, but these measures may not be consistent throughout trainingÂ [52, 59] such that they cannot provide a useful estimate of the heterogeneity which should be invariant during training. These metrics may also simply not be obtainable in practiceÂ [60]. The work ofÂ [91] considers the use of a client-relationship matrix, but such matrix may be too large (K2superscriptğ¾2K^{2} elements) and too noisy under privacy as we may need to directly or implicitly noise every coordinate of the matrix. Directly estimating the dataset statistics may also be challenging, since silos may apply custom dataset transformations (e.g.Â standardization or augmentation) that can drastically alter such statistics without affecting the learning dynamics.

  • â€¢

    The estimated heterogeneity may have high variance. In addition to the above, heterogeneity would generally be measured on the client distribution (as some form of â€œvarianceâ€ across clients, as inÂ [52]), but there is generally a limited number of clients in cross-silo settings, meaning that this estimated â€œvarianceâ€ as a measure of heterogeneity may itself have high variance. Moreoever, such measures must also be estimated privately, which means that it would have even higher variance from the additional noise. This could be problematic since the best hyperparameter for personalization may depend on such heterogeneity measure (as is the case for MR-MTL in simplified settings), and the precision of a potential auto-tuning precedure may suffer as a result.

  • â€¢

    Auto-tuning procedures may need to be developed specifically for each method. For example, local finetuning may use the number of federated training rounds as the hyperparameter for determining â€œhow muchâ€ to personalize, but such hyperparameter would likely be auto-tuned in a drastically different way compared to auto-tuning for Î»ğœ†\lambda for MR-MTL. It is in general an open question as to whether method-specific auto-tuning procedures will always outperform the simple randomized procedure described in SectionÂ F.1, in terms of both precision and privacy overhead.

Appendix H Additional Experimental Results

H.1 Local Finetuning (Extension of Fig.Â 2)

In Fig.Â 2, we made the observation that local finetuningÂ [99, 104, 19] as a personalization strategy (warm-starting from a global model and continue training using local data) may not always improve utility as expected. Extending on Fig.Â 2, we examine the behavior of local finetuning starting at different stages of training (under a fixed total number of rounds) as well as under varying privacy budgets in Fig.Â A2. We observe that the phenomenon illustrated in Fig.Â 2 is indeed reflected across different settings: as soon as local finetuning begins, the DP utility gap can quickly widen, and the utility of finetuning under privacy can roughly reduce to the utility of local training.

Note, however, that these observations serve to give insights into an interesting behavior of local finetuning under silo-specific sample-level DP and do not preclude the possibility that local finetuning can still outperform both local training and FedAvg. Indeed, local finetuning was observed to outperform local training in, e.g., Fig.Â 3Â (d) and Fig.Â A8.

H.2 Utility of MR-MTL as a Function of Î»ğœ†\lambda (Extension of Fig.Â 5)

We also extend on Fig.Â 5 to consider varying privacy budgets, and the results are shown in Fig.Â A3 (Vehicle), Fig.Â A4 (School), and Fig.Â A5 (Heterogeneous CIFAR-10). Note that on School, the test metric is MSE thus lower is better. There are several notable observations:

  • â€¢

    Î»âˆ—superscriptğœ†\lambda^{*} decreases as Îµğœ€\varepsilon grows (weaker privacy): With weaker privacy (larger Îµğœ€\varepsilon), we have a smaller optimal Î»âˆ—superscriptğœ†\lambda^{*} (i.e. the location of the utility â€œbumpâ€ under DP gradually shifts to the left). This behavior is characterized by TheoremÂ 6.3, where under stronger privacy, silos benefit from more federation as a means to reduce the effect of privacy noise.

  • â€¢

    MR-MTL does not always outperform FedAvg (at high privacy regimes): One minor caveat is that PropositionÂ 6.6 says that the utility gap from MR-MTL to FedAvg is always nonnegative under federated mean estimation; however, as discussed in SectionsÂ SectionÂ 5 and SectionÂ 6, MR-MTL does not approach FedAvg with larger Î»ğœ†\lambda in general learning settings since the MR-MTL objective may become too hard to solve via (DP-)SGD. Thus, despite its utility advantage over local training at Î»âˆ—superscriptğœ†\lambda^{*}, it may never reach the performance of FedAvg. See, e.g., subplots of Îµâˆˆ[0.1,0.2]ğœ€0.10.2\varepsilon\in[0.1,0.2] in Fig.Â A3.

  • â€¢

    Utility advantage of MR-MTLÂ (Î»âˆ—superscriptğœ†\lambda^{*}) over local/FedAvg changes with Îµğœ€\varepsilon: Observe that with larger Îµğœ€\varepsilon, the utility advantage of MR-MTLÂ (Î»âˆ—superscriptğœ†\lambda^{*}) is larger compared to FedAvg and is smaller compared to local training. This behavior is characterized by PropositionsÂ 6.5 andÂ 6.6.

Note also that for Heterogeneous CIFAR-10 (Fig.Â A5), DittoÂ [57] exhibits a slightly different interpolation behavior compared to MR-MTL (e.g.Â it has larger optimal Î»âˆ—superscriptğœ†\lambda^{*} under privacy), though at Î»âˆ—superscriptğœ†\lambda^{*} its utility underperforms that of MR-MTL under privacy.

H.3 Subsampled ADNI Dataset

We further evaluate the suite of personalization methods on the subsampled ADNI dataset, and the results are shown in Fig.Â A6. There are several notable observations:

  1. 1.

    MR-MTL is essentially recovering local training due to the high degree of heterogeneity present in this dataset, with Î»âˆ—â‰ˆ0superscriptğœ†0\lambda^{*}\approx 0 for most Îµğœ€\varepsilon values except around Îµâ‰ˆ3.5ğœ€3.5\varepsilon\approx 3.5 (annotated with arrows in Fig.Â A6Â (a, b)).

  2. 2.

    Unlike results on other datasets, the privacy regime of interest where MR-MTL outperforms both local/FedAvg (around Îµâ‰ˆ4ğœ€4\varepsilon\approx 4) is extremely narrow, compared to Îµâ‰ˆ0.5ğœ€0.5\varepsilon\approx 0.5 for Vehicle (Fig.Â 3Â (a)), Îµâ‰ˆ6ğœ€6\varepsilon\approx 6 for School (Fig.Â 3Â (b)), and Îµâ‰ˆ1.5ğœ€1.5\varepsilon\approx 1.5 for GLEAM (Fig.Â 3Â (c)). The utility advantage of MR-MTL is also insignificant.

  3. 3.

    The underlying heterogeneity structure of the dataset is rather pathological in that it is not ameanable to both mean-regularization and clustering. First, observe from Fig.Â A6Â (a) that MR-MTL still opts for a small Î»âˆ—superscriptğœ†\lambda^{*} in high-privacy regimes even when FedAvg performs better; one would expect MR-MTL to opt for a larger Î»ğœ†\lambda for lower DP noise (at a cost of higher heterogeneity). Second, from Fig.Â A6Â (b, c), we observe that both clustering and cluster-preconditoning did not lead to significant utility improvements, although the latter reduces the degree of heterogeneity and allows MR-MTL to opt for a larger Î»âˆ—superscriptğœ†\lambda^{*} in the privacy regime of interest.

In general, determining how to better model such heterogeneity (especially in high privacy regimes) is an interesting direction of future work.

H.4 Additional Discussions

Behavior on larger privacy budgets (Fig.Â A7).â€‚We extend the results on Vehicle (Fig.Â 3Â (a, b)) by considering larger privacy budgets, and the results are shown in Fig.Â A7. We note that as privacy requirement loosens, personalized learning (where each silo maintains its own model) tend to perform better than the case where models are shared across clients (FedAvg and IFCA). This is expected as clients in cross-silo datasets tend to have sufficient data for learning a good local model. Moreover, this also means MR-MTL remains competitive as it can use a smaller Î»ğœ†\lambda.

Effect of dataset subsampling (Fig.Â A8).â€‚Subsampling local datasets would in principle turn the cross-silo learning setting closer to a cross-device learning setting, in which local training becomes less attractive as due to insufficient local data and may opt for federated training despite data heterogeneity. In Fig.Â A8, we examine this behavior on the School dataset by using different train/test split ratios of 80%/20%, 50%/50%, and 20%/80%. We observe that with less local training data: (1) FedAvg performs better since silos benefit from federation despite data heterogeneity; (2) the cross-over point between local training and FedAvg shifts to larger Îµğœ€\varepsilon (or they may not be a cross-over point); and (3) MR-MTL may no longer provide an optimal point on the personalization spectrum, since small local datasets with silo-specific sample-level DP necessitate a larger Î»ğœ†\lambda (cf.Â TheoremÂ 6.3) but MR-MTL may not recover FedAvg under (DP-)SGD. In these cases, client-level DP protection (as is commonly used for cross-device FL) may be more appropriate.
